FedFed: Feature Distillation against Data Heterogeneity in Federated Learning

Zhiqin Yang1  Yonggang Zhang2∗  Yu Zheng3  Xinmei Tian5  
Hao Peng1,6  Tongliang Liu4  Bo Han2  
1Beihang University  2Hong Kong Baptist University  3Chinese University of Hong Kong
4The University of Sydney  5University of Science and Technology of China
6 Kunming University of Science and Technology Equal contributions. Corresponding author (penghao@act.buaa.edu.cn)
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) typically faces data heterogeneity, i.e., distribution shifting among clients. Sharing clients’ information has shown great potentiality in mitigating data heterogeneity, yet incurs a dilemma in preserving privacy and promoting model performance. To alleviate the dilemma, we raise a fundamental question: Is it possible to share partial features in the data to tackle data heterogeneity? In this work, we give an affirmative answer to this question by proposing a novel approach called Federated Feature distillation (FedFed). Specifically, FedFed partitions data into performance-sensitive features (i.e., greatly contributing to model performance) and performance-robust features (i.e., limitedly contributing to model performance). The performance-sensitive features are globally shared to mitigate data heterogeneity, while the performance-robust features are kept locally. FedFed enables clients to train models over local and shared data. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate the efficacy of FedFed in promoting model performance. The code is available at https://github.com/visitworld123/FedFed.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL), beneficial for training over multiple distributed data sources, has recently received increasing attention (kairouz2021advances, ; li2021survey, ; yang2019federated, ). In FL, many clients collaboratively train a global model by aggregating gradients (or model parameters) without the need to share local data. However, the major concern is heterogeneity issues (mcmahan2017communication, ; li2022federated, ; li2020federated, ) caused by Non-IID distribution of distributed data and diverse computing capability across clients. The heterogeneity issues can cause unstable model convergence and degraded prediction accuracy, hindering further FL deployments in practice (kairouz2021advances, ).

To address the heterogeneity challenge, the seminal work, federated averaging (FedAvg), introduces the model aggregation of locally trained models (mcmahan2017communication, ). It addresses the diversity of computing and communication but still faces the issue of client drift induced by data heterogeneity (karimireddy2020scaffold, ). Therefore, a branch of works for defending data heterogeneity has been explored by devising new learning objectives (li2020federated, ), aggregation strategies (yurochkin2019bayesian, ), and constructing shareable information across clients (zhao2018federated, ). Among explorations as aforementioned, sharing clients’ information has been considered to be a straightforward and promising approach to mitigate data heterogeneity (zhao2018federated, ; luo2021no, ).

However, the dilemma of preserving data privacy and promoting model performance hinders the practical effectiveness of the information-sharing strategy. Specifically, it shows that a limited amount of shared data could significantly improve model performance (zhao2018federated, ). Unfortunately, no matter for sharing raw data, synthesized data, logits, or statistical information (luo2021no, ; goetz2020federated, ; hao2021towards, ; karimireddy2020scaffold, ) can incur privacy concerns (nasr2019comprehensive, ; mothukuri2021survey, ; yan2022membership, ). Injecting random noise to data provides provable security for protecting privacy (dppaper, ; du2023dpforward, ). Yet, the primary concern for applying noise to data lies in performance degradation (tramer2020differentially, ) as the injected noise negatively contributes to model performance. Thus, perfectly playing the role of shared information requires tackling the dilemma of data privacy and model performance.

We revisit the purpose of sharing information to alleviate the dilemma in information sharing and performance improvements and ask:

Q.1 Is it possible to share partial features in the data to mitigate heterogeneity in FL? This question is fundamental to reaching a new phase for mitigating heterogeneity with the information-sharing strategy. Inspired by the partition strategy of spurious feature and robust feature (zhang2021adversarial, ), the privacy and performance dilemma could be solved if the data features were separated into performance-robust and performance-sensitive parts without overlapping, where the performance-robust features contain almost all the information in the data. Namely, the performance-robust features that limitedly contribute to model performance are kept locally. Meanwhile, the performance-sensitive features that could contribute to model generalization are selected to be shared across clients. Accordingly, the server can construct a global dataset using the shared performance-sensitive features, which enables clients to train their models over the local and shared data.

Q.2 How to divide data into performance-robust features and performance-sensitive features? The question is inherently related to the spirit of the information bottleneck (IB) method (IB0, ). In IB, ideal features should discard all information in data features except for the minimal sufficient information for generalization (IB, ). Concerning the information-sharing and performance-improvement dilemma, the features discarded in IB may contain performance-robust features, i.e., private information, thus, they are unnecessary to be shared for heterogeneity mitigation. Meanwhile, the performance-sensitive features contain information for generalization, which are the minimum sufficient information and should be shared across clients for heterogeneity mitigation. Therefore, IB provides an information-theoretic perspective of dividing data features for heterogeneity mitigation in FL.

Q.3 What if performance-sensitive features contain private information? This question lies in the fact that a non-trivial information-sharing strategy should contain necessary data information to mitigate the issue of data heterogeneity. That is, the information-sharing strategy unavoidably causes privacy risks. Fortunately, we can follow the conventional style in applying random noise to protect performance-sensitive features because the noise injection approach can provide a de facto standard way for provable security (dppaper, ). Notably, applying random noise to performance-sensitive features differs from applying random noise for all data features. More specifically, sharing partial features in the data is more accessible to preserve privacy than sharing complete data features, which is fortunately consistent with our theoretical analysis, see Theorem 3.3 in Sec. 3.3.

Our Solution. Built upon the above analysis, we propose a novel framework, named Federated Feature distillation (FedFed), to tackle data heterogeneity by generating and sharing performance-sensitive features. According to the question Q.1, FedFed introduces a competitive mechanism by decomposing data features 𝐱∈ℝd𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} with dimension d𝑑d into performance-robust features 𝐱r∈ℝdsubscript𝐱𝑟superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}_{r}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and performance-sensitive features 𝐱s∈ℝdsubscript𝐱𝑠superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}_{s}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, i.e., 𝐱=𝐱r+𝐱s𝐱subscript𝐱𝑟subscript𝐱𝑠\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{x}_{r}+\mathbf{x}_{s}. Then following the question Q.1, FedFed generates performance-robust features 𝐱rsubscript𝐱𝑟\mathbf{x}_{r} in an IB manner for data 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}. In line with Q.1, FedFed enables clients to securely share their protected features 𝐱psubscript𝐱𝑝\mathbf{x}_{p} by applying random noise 𝐧𝐧\mathbf{n} to performance sensitive features 𝐱ssubscript𝐱𝑠\mathbf{x}_{s}, i.e., 𝐱p=𝐱s+𝐧subscript𝐱𝑝subscript𝐱𝑠𝐧\mathbf{x}_{p}=\mathbf{x}_{s}+\mathbf{n}, where 𝐧𝐧\mathbf{n} is drawn from a Gaussian distribution 𝒩​(𝟎,σs2​𝐈)𝒩0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑠𝐈\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0},\sigma^{2}_{s}\mathbf{I}) with variance σs2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑠\sigma^{2}_{s}. Finally, the server can construct a global dataset to tackle data heterogeneity using the protected features 𝐱psubscript𝐱𝑝\mathbf{x}_{p}, enabling clients to train models over the local private and globally shared data.

We deploy FedFed on four popular FL algorithms, including FedAvg (mcmahan2017communication, ), FedProx (li2020federated, ), SCAFFOLD (karimireddy2020scaffold, ), and FedNova (wang2020tackling, ). Atop them, we conduct comprehensive experiments on various scenarios regarding different amounts of clients, varying degrees of heterogeneity, and four datasets. Extensive results show that the FedFed achieves considerable performance gains in all settings.

Our contributions are summarized as follows:

  1. 1.

    We pose a foundation question to challenge the necessity of sharing all data features for mitigating heterogeneity in FL with information-sharing strategies. The question sheds light on solving the privacy and performance dilemma, in a way of sharing partial features that contribute to data heterogeneity mitigation (Sec 3.1)

  2. 2.

    To solve the dilemma in information sharing and performance improvements, we propose a new framework FedFed. In FedFed, each client performs feature distillation—partitioning local data into performance-robust and performance-sensitive features (Sec 3.2) —and shares the latter with random noise globally (Sec 3.3). Consequently, FedFed can mitigate data heterogeneity by enabling clients to train their models over the local and shared data.

  3. 3.

    We conduct comprehensive experiments to show that FedFed consistently and significantly enhances the convergence rate and generalization performance of FL models across different scenarios (Sec 4.2).

2 Preliminary

Federated Learning. Federated learning allows multiple clients to collaboratively train a global model parameterized by ϕitalic-ϕ\mathbf{\phi} without exposing clients’ data  (mcmahan2017communication, ; kairouz2021advances, ). In general, the global model aims to minimize a global objective function ℒ​(ϕ)ℒitalic-ϕ\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{\phi}) over all clients’ data distributions:

minϕ⁡ℒ​(ϕ)=∑k=1Kλk​ℒk​(ϕk),subscriptitalic-ϕℒitalic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜆𝑘subscriptℒ𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘\min_{\mathbf{\phi}}\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{\phi})=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\lambda_{k}\mathcal{L}_{k}(\mathbf{\phi}_{k}), (1)

where K𝐾K represents the total number of clients, λksubscript𝜆𝑘\lambda_{k} is the weight of the k𝑘k-th client. The local objective function ℒk​(ϕk)subscriptℒ𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘\mathcal{L}_{k}(\mathbf{\phi}_{k}) of client k𝑘k is defined on the distribution P​(Xk,Yk)𝑃subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘P(X_{k},Y_{k}) with random variables Xk,Yksubscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘X_{k},Y_{k}:

ℒk​(ϕk)≜𝔼(𝐱,𝐲)∼P​(Xk,Yk)​ℓ​(ϕk;𝐱,𝐲),≜subscriptℒ𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝐲𝑃subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘ℓsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘𝐱𝐲\mathcal{L}_{k}(\mathbf{\phi}_{k})\triangleq\mathbb{E}_{(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y})\sim P(X_{k},Y_{k})}\ell(\mathbf{\phi}_{k};\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}), (2)

where 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} is input data with its label 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} and ℓ​(⋅)ℓ⋅\ell(\cdot) stands for the loss function, e.g., cross-entropy loss. Due to the distributed property of clients’ data, the global objective function ℒ​(ϕ)ℒitalic-ϕ\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{\phi}) is optimized round-by-round. Specifically, within the r𝑟r-th communication round, a set of clients C𝐶C are selected to perform local training on their private data, resulting in |C|𝐶|C| optimized models {ϕkr}k=1|C|subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑟𝑘𝐶𝑘1\{\mathbf{\phi}^{r}_{k}\}^{|C|}_{k=1}. These optimized models are then sent to a central server to derive a global model for the (r+1)𝑟1(r+1)-th communication round by an aggregation mechanism A​G​G​(⋅)𝐴𝐺𝐺⋅AGG(\cdot), which may vary from different FL algorithms:

ϕr+1=A​G​G​({ϕkr}k=1|C|).superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑟1𝐴𝐺𝐺subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑟𝑘𝐶𝑘1\mathbf{\phi}^{r+1}=AGG(\{\mathbf{\phi}^{r}_{k}\}^{|C|}_{k=1}). (3)

Differential Privacy. Differential privacy (dppaper, ) is a framework to quantify to what extent individual privacy in a dataset is preserved while releasing the data.

Definition 2.1.

(Differential Privacy). A randomized mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} provides (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy (DP) if for any two neighboring datasets D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} that differ in a single entry, ∀S⊆R​a​n​g​e​(ℳ)for-all𝑆𝑅𝑎𝑛𝑔𝑒ℳ\forall S\subseteq Range(\mathcal{M}),

Pr​(ℳ​(D)∈S)≤eϵ⋅Pr​(ℳ​(D′)∈S)+δ.Prℳ𝐷𝑆⋅superscript𝑒italic-ϵPrℳsuperscript𝐷′𝑆𝛿\mathrm{Pr}(\mathcal{M}(D)\in S)\leq e^{\epsilon}\cdot\mathrm{Pr}(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})\in S)+\delta.

where ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is the privacy budget and δ𝛿\delta is the failure probability.

The definition of (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP shows the difference of two neighboring datasets in the probability that the output of ℳℳ\mathcal{M} falls within an arbitrary set S𝑆S is related to ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and an error term δ𝛿\delta. Similar outputs of ℳℳ\mathcal{M} on D,D′𝐷superscript𝐷′D,D^{\prime} (i.e., smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon) represent a stronger privacy guarantee. In sum, DP as a de facto standard of quantitative privacy, provides provable security for protecting privacy.

Information Bottleneck. Traditionally, in the context of the Information Bottleneck (IB) framework, the goal is to effectively capture the information relevant to the output label Y𝑌Y, denoted as Z𝑍Z, while simultaneously achieving maximum compression of the input X𝑋X. Z𝑍Z represents the latent embedding, which serves as a compressed and informative representation of X𝑋X, preserving the essential information while minimizing redundancy. This objective can be formulated as:

ℒ𝖨𝖡=I​(X;Y|Z),s.t.I​(X;Z)≤I𝖨𝖡formulae-sequencesubscriptℒ𝖨𝖡𝐼𝑋conditional𝑌𝑍𝑠𝑡𝐼𝑋𝑍subscript𝐼𝖨𝖡\mathcal{L}_{\mathsf{IB}}=I(X;Y|Z),\quad s.t.\ I(X;Z)\leq I_{\mathsf{IB}} (4)

where I​(⋅)𝐼⋅I(\cdot) denote the mutual information and I𝖨𝖡subscript𝐼𝖨𝖡I_{\mathsf{IB}} is a constant. This function is defined as a rate-distortion problem, indicating that IB is to extract the most efficient and informative features.

3 Methodology

We detail the Federated Feature distillation (FedFed) proposed to mitigate data heterogeneity in FL. FedFed adopts the information-sharing strategy with the spirits of information bottleneck (IB). Roughly, it shares the minimal sufficient features, while keeping other features at clients111Appendix A displays FedFed’s overview. .

3.1 Motivation

Data heterogeneity inherently comes from the difference in data distribution among clients. Aggregating models without accessing data would inevitably bring performance degradation. Sharing clients’ data benefits model performance greatly, but intrinsically violates privacy.

Applying DP to protect shared data looks feasible; however, it is not a free lunch with paying the accuracy loss on the model.

Draw inspiration from the content and style partition of data causes (zhang2021adversarial, ), we investigate the dilemma in information sharing and performance improvements through a feature partition perspective. By introducing an appropriate partition, we can share performance-sensitive features while keeping performance-robust features locally. Namely, performance-sensitive features in the data are all we need for mitigating data heterogeneity!

We will elucidate the definitions of performance-sensitive features and performance-robust features. Firstly, we provide a precise definition of a valid partition (Definition 3.1), which captures the desirable attributes when partitioning features. Subsequently, adhering to the rules of a valid partition, we formalize the two types of features (Definition 3.2).

Definition 3.1.

(Valid Partition). A partition strategy is to partition a variable X𝑋X into two parts in the same measure space such that X=X1+X2𝑋subscript𝑋1subscript𝑋2X=X_{1}+X_{2}. We say the partition strategy is valid if it holds: (i) H​(X1,X2|X)=0𝐻subscript𝑋1conditionalsubscript𝑋2𝑋0H(X_{1},X_{2}|X)=0; (ii) H​(X|X1,X2)=0𝐻conditional𝑋subscript𝑋1subscript𝑋20H(X|X_{1},X_{2})=0; (iii) I​(X1;X2)=0𝐼subscript𝑋1subscript𝑋20I(X_{1};X_{2})=0; where H​(⋅)𝐻⋅H(\cdot) denotes the information entropy and I​(⋅)𝐼⋅I(\cdot) is the mutual information.

Definition 3.2.

(Performance-sensitive and Performance-robust Features). Let X=Xs+Xr𝑋subscript𝑋𝑠subscript𝑋𝑟X=X_{s}+X_{r} be a valid partition strategy. We say Xssubscript𝑋𝑠X_{s} are performance-sensitive features such that I​(X;Y|Xs)=0𝐼𝑋conditional𝑌subscript𝑋𝑠0I(X;Y|X_{s})=0, where Y𝑌Y is the label of X𝑋X. Accordingly, Xrsubscript𝑋𝑟X_{r} are the performance-robust features.

Intuitively, performance-sensitive features contain all label information, while performance-robust features contain all information about the data except for the label information. More discussions about Definition 3.1 and Definition 3.2 can be found in Appendix C.1. Now, the challenge turns out to be: Can we derive performance-sensitive features to mitigate data heterogeneity? FedFed provides an affirmative answer from an IB perspective, boosting a simple yet effective data-sharing strategy.

3.2 Feature Distillation

Given the motivation above, we propose to distil features such that data features can be partitioned into performance-robust features depicting mostly data and performance-sensitive features favourable to model performance. We design feature distillation and answer Q.1 below.

We draw inspiration from the information bottleneck method (IB, ). Specifically, only minimal sufficient information is preserved in learned representations while the other features are dismissed (IB, ). This can be formulated as 222We follow the formulation used in Tishby and Zaslavsky (IB, ; tishby2015deep, ).:

minZ⁡I​(X;Y|Z),s.t.​I​(X;Z)≤I𝖨𝖡,subscript𝑍𝐼𝑋conditional𝑌𝑍s.t.𝐼𝑋𝑍subscript𝐼𝖨𝖡\min_{Z}I(X;Y|Z),\ \textit{s.t.}\ I(X;Z)\leq I_{\mathsf{IB}}, (5)

where Z𝑍Z represents the desired representation extracted from input X𝑋X with its label Y𝑌Y, I​(⋅)𝐼⋅I(\cdot) is the mutual information, and I𝖨𝖡subscript𝐼𝖨𝖡I_{\mathsf{IB}} stands for a constant. Namely, given the learned representation Z𝑍Z, the mutual information between X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y is minimized. Meanwhile, Z𝑍Z dismisses most information about the input X𝑋X so that the mutual information I​(X;Z)𝐼𝑋𝑍I(X;Z) is less than a constant I𝖨𝖡subscript𝐼𝖨𝖡I_{\mathsf{IB}}.

Similarly, in FedFed, only minimal sufficient information is necessary to be shared across clients to mitigate data heterogeneity, while the other features are dismissed before sharing data, i.e., kept locally on the client. The differences between IB and FedFed have two folds: 1) FedFed aims to make the dismissed features close to the original features (i.e., depict most private data information), while IB focuses on the dissimilarity between the preserved and original features (i.e., contain minimal sufficient information about data); 2) FedFed dismisses information in the data space while IB does that in the representation space. More specifically, the objective of feature distillation is:

minZ⁡I​(X;Y|Z),s.t.​I​(X;X−Z|Z)≥I𝖥𝖥,subscript𝑍𝐼𝑋conditional𝑌𝑍s.t.𝐼𝑋𝑋conditional𝑍𝑍subscript𝐼𝖥𝖥\min_{Z}{I(X;Y|Z)},\ \textit{s.t.}\ I(X;X-Z|Z)\geq I_{\mathsf{FF}}, (6)

where Z𝑍Z represents the performance-sensitive features in X𝑋X, Y𝑌Y is the label of X𝑋X, (X−Z)𝑋𝑍(X-Z) stands for performance-robust features that are unnecessary to be shared, and I𝖥𝖥subscript𝐼𝖥𝖥I_{\mathsf{FF}} is a constant. In Eq. (6), the (X−Z)𝑋𝑍(X-Z) should represent data mostly conditioned on performance-sensitive features Z𝑍Z, while the Z𝑍Z should contain necessary information about the label Y𝑌Y. Consequently, learning with the objective can divide data features into performance-sensitive features and performance-robust features, achieving the goal of feature distillation.

To make the feature distillation tractable, we derive an objective equal to the original objective in Eq. (6) (see Appendix C.2 for more details) for client k𝑘k as follows:

minθ−𝔼(𝐱,𝐲)∼P​(Xk,Yk)​log⁡p​(𝐲|𝐳​(𝐱;θ)),s.t.​‖𝐳​(𝐱;θ)‖22≤ρ,subscript𝜃subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝐲𝑃subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘𝑝conditional𝐲𝐳𝐱𝜃s.t.superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐳𝐱𝜃22𝜌\min_{\theta}{-\mathbb{E}_{(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y})\sim P(X_{k},Y_{k})}\log p(\mathbf{y}|\mathbf{z}(\mathbf{x};\mathbf{\theta}))},\ \textit{s.t.}\ ||\mathbf{z}(\mathbf{x};\theta)||_{2}^{2}\leq\rho, (7)

where θ𝜃\theta is the parameter to be optimized for generating performance-sensitive features 𝐳​(⋅;θ)𝐳⋅𝜃\mathbf{z}(\cdot;\theta), (𝐱,𝐲)𝐱𝐲(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}) represents the input pair drawn from the joint distribution P​(Xk,Yk)𝑃subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘P(X_{k},Y_{k}) of client k𝑘k, p​(𝐲|⋅)𝑝conditional𝐲⋅p(\mathbf{y}|\cdot) is the probability of predicting Y=𝐲𝑌𝐲Y=\mathbf{y}, and ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0 stands for a constant. The underlying insight of the objective function in Eq. (7) is intuitive. Specifically, the learned performance-sensitive features 𝐳​(⋅;θ)𝐳⋅𝜃\mathbf{z}(\cdot;\theta) are capable of predicting the label 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} while having the minimal ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm.

Unfortunately, the original formulation in Eq. (7) can hardly be used for dividing data features. This is because the feature distillation in Eq. 7 cannot make the preserved features 𝐱−𝐳​(𝐱;θ)𝐱𝐳𝐱𝜃\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{z}(\mathbf{x};\theta) similar to the raw features 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}. Namely, the original Eq. (7) cannot guarantee the desired property of the preserved features. To solve the problem, we propose an explicit competition mechanism in the data space. Specifically, we model preserved features, i.e., performance-robust features, with q​(𝐱;θ)𝑞𝐱𝜃q(\mathbf{x};\theta) explicitly and model the performance-sensitive features 𝐳​(𝐱;θ)≜𝐱−q​(𝐱;θ)≜𝐳𝐱𝜃𝐱𝑞𝐱𝜃\mathbf{z}(\mathbf{x};\theta)\triangleq\mathbf{x}-q(\mathbf{x};\theta) implicitly:

minθ−𝔼(𝐱,𝐲)∼P​(Xk,Yk)​log⁡p​(𝐲|𝐱−q​(𝐱;θ)),s.t.​‖𝐱−q​(𝐱;θ)‖22≤ρ.subscript𝜃subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝐲𝑃subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘𝑝conditional𝐲𝐱𝑞𝐱𝜃s.t.superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐱𝑞𝐱𝜃22𝜌\begin{split}\min_{\theta}-&\mathbb{E}_{(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y})\sim P(X_{k},Y_{k})}\log p(\mathbf{y}|\mathbf{x}-q(\mathbf{x};\theta)),\ \textit{s.t.}\ ||\mathbf{x}-q(\mathbf{x};\theta)||_{2}^{2}\leq\rho.\end{split} (8)

Thus, by Eq. 8, performance-sensitive features can predict labels and performance-robust features are almost the same as raw features.

The realization of Eq. (8) is straightforward. To be specific, we can employ a generative model parameterized with θ𝜃\theta to generate performance-robust features, i.e., q​(𝐱;θ)𝑞𝐱𝜃q(\mathbf{x};\theta) in Eq. (8). Meanwhile, we train a local classifier f​(⋅;𝐰k)𝑓⋅subscript𝐰𝑘f(\cdot;\mathbf{w}_{k}) parameterized with 𝐰ksubscript𝐰𝑘\mathbf{w}_{k} for client-k𝑘k to model the process of predicting labels, i.e., −log⁡p​(𝐲|⋅)𝑝conditional𝐲⋅-\log p(\mathbf{y}|\cdot) in Eq. (8). Accordingly, the realization of feature distillation is formulated as follows with 𝐳​(𝐱;θ)≜𝐱−q​(𝐱;θ)≜𝐳𝐱𝜃𝐱𝑞𝐱𝜃\mathbf{z}(\mathbf{x};\theta)\triangleq\mathbf{x}-q(\mathbf{x};\theta):

minθ,𝐰k−𝔼(𝐱,𝐲)∼P​(Xk,Xk)​ℓ​(f​(𝐳​(𝐱;θ);𝐰k),𝐲),s.t.​‖𝐳​(𝐱;θ)‖22≤ρ,subscript𝜃subscript𝐰𝑘subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝐲𝑃subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑋𝑘ℓ𝑓𝐳𝐱𝜃subscript𝐰𝑘𝐲s.t.superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐳𝐱𝜃22𝜌\begin{split}\min_{\theta,\mathbf{w}_{k}}-&\mathbb{E}_{(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y})\sim P(X_{k},X_{k})}\ell(f(\mathbf{z}(\mathbf{x};\theta);\mathbf{w}_{k}),\mathbf{y}),\ \textit{s.t.}||\mathbf{z}(\mathbf{x};\theta)||_{2}^{2}\leq\rho,\end{split} (9)

where ℓ​(⋅)ℓ⋅\ell(\cdot) is the cross-entropy loss, q​(𝐱;θ)𝑞𝐱𝜃q(\mathbf{x};\theta) stands for a generative model, and ρ𝜌\rho represents a tunable hyper-parameter. Built upon Eq. (9), we can perform feature distillation, namely, the outputs of a generator q​(𝐱;θ)𝑞𝐱𝜃q(\mathbf{x};\theta) serve as performance-robust features and 𝐱−q​(𝐱;θ)𝐱𝑞𝐱𝜃\mathbf{x}-q(\mathbf{x};\theta) are used as performance-sensitive features. We merely share 𝐱−q​(𝐱;θ)𝐱𝑞𝐱𝜃\mathbf{x}-q(\mathbf{x};\theta) to tackle data heterogeneity by training models over both local and shared data. Algorithm 1 summarizes the procedure of feature distillation.

3.3 Protection for Performance-Sensitive Features

Until now, we have intentionally overlooked the overlap between performance-sensitive features and performance-robust features. Since we prioritize data heterogeneity, overlapping is almost unavoidable in practice, i.e., performance-sensitive features containing certain data privacy. Accordingly, merely sharing performance-sensitive features can risk privacy. Thus, we answer Q. 1 below.

Why employ DP? The constructed performance-sensitive features may contain individual privacy, thus, the goal of introducing a protection approach is for individual privacy. In addition, the employed protection approach is expected to be robust against privacy attacks (sp/ShokriSSS17, ; uss/0001TO21, ). According to the above analysis, differential privacy (DP) is naturally suitable in our scenario of feature distillation. Thus, we employ DP to protect performance-sensitive features before sending them to the server.

How to apply DP? Applying noise (e.g., Gaussian or Laplacian) to performance-sensitive features before sharing can protect features with DP guarantee (stoc/BlumLR08, ; dppaper, ), i.e., 𝐱p=𝐱s+𝐧subscript𝐱𝑝subscript𝐱𝑠𝐧\mathbf{x}_{p}=\mathbf{x}_{s}+\mathbf{n}. Consequently, the server can collect protected features 𝐱psubscript𝐱𝑝\mathbf{x}_{p} from clients to construct a global dataset and send the dataset back to clients. To give a vivid illustration, we provide a guessing game333We reveal the answer in Appendix F.2 in Figure 1, showing 444 images. The first image represents the DP-protected performance-sensitive features of one image (A, B, or C). It is hard to identify which one of the raw images (A, B, C) the first image belongs to.

Training with DP. The protected performance-sensitive features are shared, thus, the server can construct a globally shared dataset. Using the global dataset, clients can train local classifier f​(⋅;ϕk)𝑓⋅subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘f(\cdot;\phi_{k}) parameterized by ϕksubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘\phi_{k} with the private and shared data:

minϕk⁡𝔼(𝐱,𝐲)∼P​(Xk,Yk)​ℓ​(f​(𝐱;ϕk),𝐲)+𝔼(𝐱p,𝐲)∼P​(𝐡​(Xk),Yk)​ℓ​(f​(𝐱p;ϕk),𝐲),subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝐲𝑃subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘ℓ𝑓𝐱subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘𝐲subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑝𝐲𝑃𝐡subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘ℓ𝑓subscript𝐱𝑝subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘𝐲\begin{split}\min_{\phi_{k}}\mathbb{E}_{(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y})\sim P(X_{k},Y_{k})}\ell(f(\mathbf{x};\phi_{k}),\mathbf{y})+\mathbb{E}_{(\mathbf{x}_{p},\mathbf{y})\sim P(\mathbf{h}(X_{k}),Y_{k})}\ell(f(\mathbf{x}_{p};\phi_{k}),\mathbf{y}),\end{split} (10)

where f​(⋅;ϕk)𝑓⋅subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘f(\cdot;\phi_{k}) is trained for model aggregation, (𝐱p,𝐲)subscript𝐱𝑝𝐲(\mathbf{x}_{p},\mathbf{y}) are protected performance-sensitive features that are collected from all clients, and 𝐡​(Xk):=𝐳​(Xk)+nassign𝐡subscript𝑋𝑘𝐳subscript𝑋𝑘𝑛\mathbf{h}(X_{k}):=\mathbf{z}(X_{k})+n with noise n𝑛n. Pseudo-code of how to apply FedFed are listed in Appendix B.

DP guarantee. Following DP-SGD abadi2016deep , we employ the idea of the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm clipping relating to the selection of the noise level σ𝜎\sigma. Specifically, we realize the constraint in Eq. (9) as follows: ‖𝐳​(𝐱;θ)‖2≤ρ​‖𝐱‖subscriptnorm𝐳𝐱𝜃2𝜌norm𝐱\|\mathbf{z}(\mathbf{x};\theta)\|_{2}\leq\rho\|\mathbf{x}\|, with 0<ρ<10𝜌10<\rho<1 (i.e., ‖𝐱s‖≤ρ​‖𝐱‖normsubscript𝐱𝑠𝜌norm𝐱\|\mathbf{x}_{s}\|\leq\rho\|\mathbf{x}\|). For aligning analyses with conventional DP guarantee, we let the random mechanism on performance-robust features 𝐱rsubscript𝐱𝑟\mathbf{x}_{r} be 𝐱r+n,n∼𝒩​(0,σr2​𝐈)similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑟𝑛𝑛𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑟2𝐈\mathbf{x}_{r}+n,n\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma_{r}^{2}\mathbf{I}). Similar for performance-sensitive features, we have 𝐱s+n,n∼𝒩​(0,σs2​𝐈)similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑠𝑛𝑛𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠2𝐈\mathbf{x}_{s}+n,n\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma_{s}^{2}\mathbf{I}). Since 𝐱rsubscript𝐱𝑟\mathbf{x}_{r} is kept locally, an adversary views nothing (or random data without any entropy). This keeps equal to adding a sufficiently large noise, i.e., σr=∞subscript𝜎𝑟\sigma_{r}=\infty on 𝐱rsubscript𝐱𝑟\mathbf{x}_{r} to make it random enough. Consequently, FedFed can provide a strong privacy guarantee. Moreover, for each client, we show that FedFed requires a relatively small noise level σ𝜎\sigma for achieving identical privacy, which is given in Theorem 3.3 (detailed analysis is left in Appendix D).

Theorem 3.3.

Let σ𝜎\sigma be the noise scale for FedFed and σ′superscript𝜎′\sigma^{\prime} be the noise scale for sharing raw 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}. Given identical ϵ,δitalic-ϵ𝛿\epsilon,\delta, we attain σ<σ′𝜎superscript𝜎′\sigma<\sigma^{\prime} such that σ∝‖𝐱s‖2proportional-to𝜎superscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑠2\sigma\propto\|\mathbf{x}_{s}\|^{2}.

Besides each client, we give the privacy analysis for the FL system paired with the proposed FedFed.

Theorem 3.4 (Composition of FedFed).

For k𝑘k clients with (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy, FedFed satisfies (ϵ^δ^,1−(1−δ^)​Πi​(1−δi))subscript^italic-ϵ^𝛿11^𝛿subscriptΠ𝑖1subscript𝛿𝑖(\hat{\epsilon}_{\hat{\delta}},1-(1-\hat{\delta})\Pi_{i}(1-\delta_{i}))-differential privacy, where, ϵ^δ^=min⁡{k​ρ​R​log⁡(1/δ)σs,ρ​R​log⁡(1/δ)σs​[eρ​R​log⁡(1/δ)/σs−1eρ​R​log⁡(1/δ)/σs+1​k+ϵ​(2​k​log⁡(e+(ρ​k​R​δ^​log⁡(1/δ))/(σs2​δ^)))1/2],ρ​R​log⁡(1/δ)σs⋅[eρ​R​log⁡(1/δ)/σs−1eρ​R​log⁡(1/δ)/σs+1​k+2​k​log⁡(1/δ^)]}subscript^italic-ϵ^𝛿𝑘𝜌𝑅1𝛿subscript𝜎𝑠𝜌𝑅1𝛿subscript𝜎𝑠delimited-[]superscript𝑒𝜌𝑅1𝛿subscript𝜎𝑠1superscript𝑒𝜌𝑅1𝛿subscript𝜎𝑠1𝑘italic-ϵsuperscript2𝑘𝑒𝜌𝑘𝑅^𝛿1𝛿superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠2^𝛿12⋅𝜌𝑅1𝛿subscript𝜎𝑠delimited-[]superscript𝑒𝜌𝑅1𝛿subscript𝜎𝑠1superscript𝑒𝜌𝑅1𝛿subscript𝜎𝑠1𝑘2𝑘1^𝛿\hat{\epsilon}_{\hat{\delta}}=\min\{\frac{k\rho\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}}{\sigma_{s}},\frac{\rho\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}}{\sigma_{s}}[\frac{e^{{\rho\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}}/{\sigma_{s}}}-1}{e^{{\rho\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}}/{\sigma_{s}}}+1}k+\epsilon(2k\log(e+(\rho\sqrt{kR\hat{\delta}\log(1/\delta)})/(\sigma_{s}^{2}\hat{\delta})))^{1/2}],\frac{\rho\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}}{\sigma_{s}}\cdot\allowbreak[\frac{e^{{\rho\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}}/{\sigma_{s}}}-1}{e^{{\rho\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}}/{\sigma_{s}}}+1}k+\sqrt{2k\log(1/\hat{\delta})}]\}.

Atop composition theorem icml/KairouzOV15 , Theoreom 3.4 shows that FedFed is able to provide a strong privacy guarantee for FL systems.

4 Experiments

We organize this section in the following aspects: a) the main experimental settings that we primarily followed (Sec 4.1); b) the main results and observations of applying FedFed to existing popular FL algorithms (Sec 4.2); c) the sensitivity study of hyper-parameters on effecting model performance (Sec 4.3); and d) empirical analysis of privacy with two kinds of attacks (Sec 4.4).

4.1 Experimental Setup

Federated Non-IID Datasets. Following previous works (luo2021no, ; zhang2022federated, ), we conduct experiments over CIFAR-10, CIFAR100 (krizhevsky2009learning, ), Fashion-MNIST(FMNIST) (xiao2017fashion, ), and SVHN (netzer2011reading, ). Following (li2022federated, ), we employ latent Dirichlet sampling (LDA) (hsu2019measuring, ) to simulate Non-IID distribution. In our experiments, following (li2022federated, ; vhl, ), we set α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1 and α=0.05𝛼0.05\alpha=0.05 by LDA.

Besides, we evaluate FedFed with other two widely adopted partition strategies: #​C=k#𝐶𝑘\#C=k (mcmahan2017communication, ; li2022federated, ) and Subset method (zhao2018federated, ), mainly including label skew and quantity skew (Appendix F.1 shows more detail of data distribution).

Models, Metrics and Baselines. We use ResNet-18 (he2016deep, ) both in the feature distillation and classifier in FL. We evaluate the model performance via two popular metrics in FL: a) communication rounds and b) best accuracy. Typically, the target accuracy is set to be the best accuracy of vanilla FedAvg. As a plug-in approach, we apply FedFed to prevailing existing FL algorithms, such as FedAvg (mcmahan2017communication, ), FedProx (li2020federated, ), SCAFFOLD (karimireddy2020scaffold, ), and FedNova (wang2020tackling, ) to compare the efficiency of our method. More experimental settings and details are listed in Appendix B.1.

4.2 Main Results

Generative Model Selection. We consider two generative models in this paper to distill raw data, i.e., Resnet Generator, a kind of vanilla generator used in many works (zhu2017unpaired, ; poursaeed2018generative, ), and β𝛽\beta-VAE (higgins2016beta, ), an encoder-decoder structure by variational inference. We verify the effectiveness of FedFed with different generative models. According to results shown in Figure 2 (a), we observe that β𝛽\beta-VAE gets better performance in FedFed. Thus, we mainly report the results of β𝛽\beta-VAE in the rest.

Result Analysis. The experimental results on CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, FMNIST, and SVHN are shown respectively in Tables 1, 2, 3, and 4. It can be seen that the proposed method can consistently and significantly improve model accuracy under various settings. Moreover, FedFed can promote the convergence rate of different algorithms444 More supporting figures of convergence rate are moved to appendix F.4. Specifically, FedFed brings significant performance gain in CIFAR-10 under the K=100𝐾100K=100 setting shown in Table 1 and also notably speeds up the convergence rate in FMNIST under the α=0.05,E=1,K=10formulae-sequence𝛼0.05formulae-sequence𝐸1𝐾10\alpha=0.05,E=1,K=10 setting. However, attributable to the original FL methods almost reaching a performance bottleneck, FedFed achieves limited performance gain in SVHN and FMNIST. FedFed also has limited improvement in CIFAR-100. A possible reason is that existing methods can achieve performance comparable to centralized training. Moreover, we conducted an additional experiment involving sharing the full data with DP protection. The results, presented in Appendix F.3, indicate that sharing the full data with DP protection leads to a degradation in the performance of the FL system. This degradation occurs because protecting the full data necessitates a relatively large noise to achieve the corresponding protection strength required to safeguard performance-sensitive features.

Surprising Observations. We find that training among 100100100 clients in CIFAR-10 and CIFAR100 reaches a significant improvement (e.g., at most 40.67%percent40.6740.67\%!). A possible reason is that the missed data knowledge can be well replenished by FedFed. Moreover, all methods paired with FedFed under various settings can achieve similar prediction accuracies, demonstrating that FedFed endows FL models robustness against data heterogeneity. Table 6 shows that two kinds of heterogeneity partition cause more performance decline than LDA (α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1). Yet, FedFed attains noteworthy improvement, indicating the robustness against Non-IID partition.

4.3 Ablation Study

DP Noise. To explore the relationship between privacy level ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and prediction accuracy, we conduct experiments with different noise levels σs2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠2\sigma_{s}^{2}. As shown in Figure 2(c), the prediction accuracy decreases with increasing noise level (more results in Appendix F.5). To verify whether the FedFed is robust against the selection of noise, we also consider Laplacian noise in applying DP to privacy protection. The results of Laplacian noise are reported in Table 6, demonstrating the robustness of FedFed.

Hyper-parameters. We further evaluate the robustness of FedFed against hyper-parameters. During the feature distillation process, as the constraint parameter ρ𝜌\rho in Eq. 9 decreases, the DP strength to protect performance-sensitive features decreases, and the performance of the global model decreases, owing to the less information contained in performance-sensitive features.

4.4 Privacy Verification

Besides the theoretical analysis, we provide empirical analysis to support the privacy guarantee of FedFed. We wonder whether the globally shared data can be inferred by some attacking methods. Thus, we resort to model inversion attack (he2019model, ), widely used in the literature to reconstruct data. The results555More details and results can be found in Appendix E.1. in Figure 3 (a) and (b) indicate that FedFed could protect globally shared data. We also conduct another model inversion attack (zhang2020secret, ) and the results can be found in Appendix E.1. Additionally, we perform membership inference attack (shokri2017membership, ) to illustrate the difference between FedFed and sharing all data features with DP protection. The results illustrated in Figure 3 (c) show that noise level σ2=0.3superscript𝜎20.3\sigma^{2}=0.3 over raw data 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} can achieve similar protection as noise σs2=0.15superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠20.15\sigma_{s}^{2}=0.15 over globally shared data 𝐱psubscript𝐱𝑝\mathbf{x}_{p}, which aligns with Theorem 3.3. More details can be found in Appendix E.2

5 Related Work

Federated Learning (FL) models typically perform poorly when meeting severe Non-IID data (li2021survey, ; karimireddy2020scaffold, ). To tackle data heterogeneity, advanced works introduce various learning objectives to calibrate the updated direction of local training from being far away from the global model, e.g., FedProx(li2020federated, ), FedIR (hsu2020federated, ), SCAFFOLD (karimireddy2020scaffold, ), and MOON (li2021model, ). Designing model aggregation schemes like FedAvgM (hsu2019measuring, ), FedNova (wang2020tackling, ), FedMA (wang2020federated, ), and FedBN (li2021fedbn, ) shows the efficacy on heterogeneity mitigation. Another promising direction is the information-sharing strategy, which mainly focuses on synthesizing and sharing clients’ information to mitigate heterogeneity (zhao2018federated, ; jeong2018communication, ; long2021g, ). To avoid exposing privacy caused by the shared data, some methods utilize the statistics of data (shin2020xor, ), representations of data (hao2021towards, ), logits (chang2019cronus, ; luo2021no, ), embedding (tan2022fedproto, ). However, advanced attacks pose potential threats to methods with data-sharing strategies (zhao2020makes, ).

FedFed is inspired by (vhl, ), where pure noise is shared across clients to tackle data heterogeneity. In this work, we relax the privacy concern by sharing partial features in the data with DP protection. In addition, our work is technically similar to an adversarial learning approach (yang2021class, ). Our method distinguishes by defining various types of features and delving into the exploration of data heterogeneity within FL. More discussion can be found in Appendix G.

6 Conclusion

In this work, we propose a novel framework, called FedFed, to tackle data heterogeneity in FL by employing the promising information-sharing approach. Our work extends the research line of constructing shareable information of clients by proposing to share partial features in data. This shares a new route of improving training performance and maintaining privacy in the meantime. Furthermore, FedFed has served as a source of inspiration for a new direction focused on improving performance in open-set scenarios (fang2022out, ). Another avenue of exploration involves deploying FedFed in other real-time FL application scenarios, such as recommendation systems (liu2022federated, ) and medical image analysis (zhou2022sparse, ), to uncover its potential benefits.

Limitation. Limited local hardware resources may limit the power of FedFed, since FedFed introduces some extra overheads like communication overheads and storage overheads. We leave it as future work to explore a hardware-friendly version. Additionally, FedFed raises potential privacy concerns that we leave as a future research exploration, such as integrating cryptography sp/NgC23 . We anticipate that our work will inspire further investigations to comprehensively evaluate the privacy risks associated with information-sharing strategies aimed at mitigating data heterogeneity.

Supplementary Material for FedFed: Feature Distillation against Data Heterogeneity in Federated Learning

Appendix A Overview of FedFed Framework

The training process of the federated learning system with FedFed can be summarized into four phases. Firstly, every participant of FL distils the local private raw data 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} and decouples 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} into performance-robust features 𝐱rsubscript𝐱𝑟\mathbf{x}_{r} and performance-sensitive features 𝐱ssubscript𝐱𝑠\mathbf{x}_{s} during the feature distillation phase. Then all clients send 𝐱psubscript𝐱𝑝\mathbf{x}_{p} to construct a global dataset, 𝐱ssubscript𝐱𝑠\mathbf{x}_{s} with DP protection and keep 𝐱rsubscript𝐱𝑟\mathbf{x}_{r} locally. In the local training phase, the selected clients sample a subset from the globally shared dataset and update the local model with local raw data 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} and sampled information 𝐱psubscript𝐱𝑝\mathbf{x}_{p} from server. Finally, clients upload the latest local model and aggregate a global model based on a certain aggregation algorithm, like the weighted average strategy in FedAvg. Figure 4 shows the overview of FedFed framework, while Figure 5 depicts its pipeline of feature distillation. The loss function of feature distillation in Figure 5 is Eq (9).

Appendix B Federated Learning Algorithms with FedFed

B.1 Implementation Details

We list all relevant parameters in this paper in Table 7. We fine-tune learning rate in the set of {0.0001,0.001,0.01,0.1}0.00010.0010.010.1\{0.0001,0.001,0.01,0.1\} and report the best results and corresponding learning rate. Whereas, we use 0.01 as the learning rate. In our work, we deploy FedFed on SCAFFOLD and set the learning rate ηksubscript𝜂𝑘\eta_{k} to 0.0001 for the SVHN dataset. Furthermore, we use ηk=0.001subscript𝜂𝑘0.001\eta_{k}=0.001 in SVHN while FedNove is deployed with our method.

The batch size is set as 64 when K=10𝐾10K=10 and 32 for K=100𝐾100K=100. On the server side, we select 5 clients for aggregation per round when K=10𝐾10K=10, and 10 clients per round when K=100𝐾100K=100. This corresponds to a sampling rate of 50% for 10 clients (K=10𝐾10K=10) and 10% for 100 clients (K=100𝐾100K=100). The noise level in our experiments is 𝒩​(0,0.15)𝒩00.15\mathcal{N}(0,0.15). Besides, all experiments are performed on Python 3.8, 36 core 3.00GHz Intel Core i9 CPU, and NVIDIA RTX A6000 GPUs.

minϕk⁡𝔼(𝐱,𝐲)∼P​(Xk,Xk)​ℓ​(f​(𝐱;ϕk),𝐲)+𝔼(𝐱p,𝐲)∼P​(𝐡​(Xk),Yk)​ℓ​(f​(𝐱p;ϕk),𝐲)+μ2​‖ϕ−ϕr‖2,subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝐲𝑃subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑋𝑘ℓ𝑓𝐱subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘𝐲subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑝𝐲𝑃𝐡subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘ℓ𝑓subscript𝐱𝑝subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘𝐲𝜇2superscriptnormitalic-ϕsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑟2\min_{\phi_{k}}\mathbb{E}_{(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y})\sim P(X_{k},X_{k})}\ell(f(\mathbf{x};\phi_{k}),\mathbf{y})+\mathbb{E}_{(\mathbf{x}_{p},\mathbf{y})\sim P(\mathbf{h}(X_{k}),Y_{k})}\ell(f(\mathbf{x}_{p};\phi_{k}),\mathbf{y})+{\color[rgb]{0,0,1}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,1}\frac{\mu}{2}||\phi-\phi^{r}||^{2}}, (11)

SCAFFOLD attempts to estimate the client shift degree to correct client update direction. Particularly, it works through server control variate c𝑐c and client control variate cksubscript𝑐𝑘c_{k} of client k. SCAFFOLD with FedFed is summarized in Algorithm 3. And FedNova is proposed to resolve the objective inconsistency for defying data heterogeneity. The outline of our plugin deploys on FedNova in the Algorithm 4. In accordance with our process of how to apply FedFed, every participant of the FL system can deploy our framework easily without any modification of objective function or aggregation scheme.

Appendix C Full Analysis on Information Theory Perspective

C.1 Features Partition

From an information theory perspective, we present formal definitions, namely Definition 3.1 and Definition 3.2, to define performance-robust features and performance-sensitive features. Specifically, Definition 3.1 captures the desirable attributes when we partition the features, which are abstracted to be a variable in general. A valid partition should maintain all information of the original variable X𝑋X losslessly. That is, neither extra information is introduced nor key information is lost. So we can get (i) and (ii) in Definition 3.1. After determining the measure space, we partition the X𝑋X to be X=X1+X2𝑋subscript𝑋1subscript𝑋2X=X_{1}+X_{2}. The mutual information of X1subscript𝑋1X_{1} and X2subscript𝑋2X_{2} is none. Here, X1subscript𝑋1X_{1} and X2subscript𝑋2X_{2} can be symmetric. Or saying, there is no overlap between X1subscript𝑋1X_{1} and X2subscript𝑋2X_{2}, as described by (iii) in Definition 3.1.

Built upon the Definition 3.1, we present the definition of performance-sensitive features and performance-robust features, as in Definition 3.2. Intuitively, performance-sensitive features contain all label information, while performance-robust features contains all information about the data except for the label information. That is, the features to be partitioned are either performance-sensitive features or performance-robust features.

C.2 FedFed on Information Bottleneck Perspective

In this section, we analyse FedFed under an information bottleneck(IB) aspect. In conventional, information bottleneck [21] can be formalized as:

minZ⁡I​(X;Y|Z),s.t.​I​(X;Z)≤Ic.subscript𝑍𝐼𝑋conditional𝑌𝑍s.t.𝐼𝑋𝑍subscript𝐼𝑐\min_{Z}I(X;Y|Z),\ \textit{s.t.}\ I(X;Z)\leq I_{c}. (12)

where to restrict the complexity of encoding Z𝑍Z. Information entropy is denoted as H​(⋅)𝐻⋅H(\cdot) and I​(⋅;⋅)𝐼⋅⋅I(\cdot;\cdot) is the mutual information of two variables. In FedFed, our competitive mechanism stems from IB getting the following definition:

minZ⁡I​(X;Y|Z),s.t.​I​(X−Z;X|Z)≥Ic,⇔minZ⁡H​(Y|Z),s.t.​H​(Z)≤Hc,⇔min𝐳−𝔼​log⁡p​(𝐲|𝐳),s.t.​‖𝐳‖22≤ρ.\begin{split}&\min_{Z}{I(X;Y|Z)},\ \textit{s.t.}\ I(X-Z;X|Z)\geq I_{c},\\ &\Leftrightarrow\min_{Z}H(Y|Z),\ \textit{s.t.}\ H(Z)\leq H_{c},\\ &\Leftrightarrow\min_{\mathbf{z}}{-\mathbb{E}\ \log p(\mathbf{y}|\mathbf{z})},\ \textit{s.t.}\ ||\mathbf{z}||_{2}^{2}\leq\rho.\end{split} (13)

According to our framework, 𝐳𝐳\mathbf{z} can be defined as: 𝐳=𝐳−𝐱r=𝐱−q​(𝐱;θ)𝐳𝐳subscript𝐱𝑟𝐱𝑞𝐱𝜃\mathbf{z}=\mathbf{z}-\mathbf{x}_{r}=\mathbf{x}-q(\mathbf{x};\theta), and then we can the get the optimization view of FedFed:

minθ−𝔼(𝐱,𝐲)∼P​(Xk,Yk)​log⁡p​(𝐲|𝐱−q​(𝐱;θ)),s.t.​‖𝐱−q​(𝐱;θ)‖22≤ρ.subscript𝜃subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝐲𝑃subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘𝑝conditional𝐲𝐱𝑞𝐱𝜃s.t.superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐱𝑞𝐱𝜃22𝜌\min_{\theta}{-\mathbb{E}_{(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y})\sim P(X_{k},Y_{k})}\log p(\mathbf{y}|\mathbf{x}-q(\mathbf{x};\theta))},\ \textit{s.t.}\ ||\mathbf{x}-q(\mathbf{x};\theta)||_{2}^{2}\leq\rho. (14)

Ultimately, in an information bottleneck perspective, minθ−𝔼(𝐱,𝐲)∼P​(Xk,Yk)​log⁡p​(𝐲|𝐱−q​(𝐱;θ))subscript𝜃subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝐲𝑃subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘𝑝conditional𝐲𝐱𝑞𝐱𝜃\min_{\theta}{-\mathbb{E}_{(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y})\sim P(X_{k},Y_{k})}\log p(\mathbf{y}|\mathbf{x}-q(\mathbf{x};\theta))} intend to contain more information that can be used for generalization. ‖𝐱−q​(𝐱;θ)‖22≤ρsuperscriptsubscriptnorm𝐱𝑞𝐱𝜃22𝜌||\mathbf{x}-q(\mathbf{x};\theta)||_{2}^{2}\leq\rho aims at distilling raw data for minimum features which means maximal compression of 𝐱ssubscript𝐱𝑠\mathbf{x}_{s}.

Proof.

To get Eq (13), we firstly have:

I​(X;Y|Z)=I​(X;Y)−I​(X;Y;Z)=H​(X)+H​(Y)−H​(X,Y)−[I​(Y;Z)−I​(Y;Z|X)]=H​(X)+H​(Y)−H​(X,Y)−[H​(Y)+H​(Z)−H​(Y,Z)]+[H​(Y|X)−H​(Y|X,Z)]=H​(X)+H​(Y)−H​(X,Y)−H​(Y)−H​(Z)+H​(Y,Z)+H​(Y|X)−H​(Y|X,Z)=H​(X)−H​(X,Y)−H​(Z)+H​(Y,Z)+H​(Y|X)−H​(Y|X,Z)=H​(Y,Z)−H​(Z)−H​(Y|X,Z)=H​(Z)+H​(Y|Z)−H​(Z)−H​(Y|X,Z)=H​(Y|Z)−H​(Y|X,Z)=H​(Y|Z)−H​(Y|X).I​(X−Z;X|Z)=I​(X−Z;X)−I​(X−Z;X;Z)=H​(X−Z)+H​(x)−H​(X−Z,X)−[I​(X;Z)−I​(X;Z|X−Z)]=H​(X−Z)+H​(X)−H​(X−Z,X)−[H​(X)+H​(Z)−H​(X,Z)]+[H​(X|X−Z)−H​(X|X−Z,Z)]=H​(X−Z)+H​(X)−H​(X−Z,X)−H​(X)−H​(Z)+H​(X,Z)+H​(X|X−Z)−H​(X|X−Z,Z)=H​(X−Z)−H​(X−Z,X)−H​(Z)+H​(X,Z)+H​(X|X−Z)=H​(X−Z)−H​(X)−H​(Z)+H​(X)+H​(X|X−Z)=H​(X−Z)−H​(Z)+H​(X|X−Z)=H​(X,X−Z)−H​(Z)=H​(X)−H​(Z).I​(X−Z;X|Z)≥Ic⇔H​(X)−H​(Z)≥Ic⇒H​(Z)≤H​(x)−Ic=Hc⇒H​(Z)≤Hc.\begin{split}I(X;Y|Z)&=I(X;Y)-I(X;Y;Z)\\ &=H(X)+H(Y)-H(X,Y)-[I(Y;Z)-I(Y;Z|X)]\\ &=H(X)+H(Y)-H(X,Y)-[H(Y)+H(Z)-H(Y,Z)]\\ &+[H(Y|X)-H(Y|X,Z)]\\ &=H(X)+H(Y)-H(X,Y)-H(Y)-H(Z)\\ &+H(Y,Z)+H(Y|X)-H(Y|X,Z)\\ &=H(X)-H(X,Y)-H(Z)+H(Y,Z)+H(Y|X)-H(Y|X,Z)\\ &=H(Y,Z)-H(Z)-H(Y|X,Z)\\ &=H(Z)+H(Y|Z)-H(Z)-H(Y|X,Z)\\ &=H(Y|Z)-H(Y|X,Z)\\ &=H(Y|Z)-H(Y|X).\\ I(X-Z;X|Z)&=I(X-Z;X)-I(X-Z;X;Z)\\ &=H(X-Z)+H(x)-H(X-Z,X)-[I(X;Z)-I(X;Z|X-Z)]\\ &=H(X-Z)+H(X)-H(X-Z,X)-[H(X)+H(Z)-H(X,Z)]\\ &+[H(X|X-Z)-H(X|X-Z,Z)]\\ &=H(X-Z)+H(X)-H(X-Z,X)-H(X)-H(Z)\\ &+H(X,Z)+H(X|X-Z)-H(X|X-Z,Z)\\ &=H(X-Z)-H(X-Z,X)-H(Z)+H(X,Z)+H(X|X-Z)\\ &=H(X-Z)-H(X)-H(Z)+H(X)+H(X|X-Z)\\ &=H(X-Z)-H(Z)+H(X|X-Z)\\ &=H(X,X-Z)-H(Z)\\ &=H(X)-H(Z).\\ I(X-Z;X|Z)&\geq I_{c}\Leftrightarrow H(X)-H(Z)\geq I_{c}\Rightarrow H(Z)\leq H(x)-I_{c}=H_{c}\Rightarrow H(Z)\leq H_{c}.\end{split} (15)

Then, we get minZ⁡I​(X;Y|Z),s.t.​I​(X−Z;X|Z)≥Ic⇔minZ⁡H​(Y|Z),s.t.​H​(Z)≤Hc.⇔subscript𝑍𝐼𝑋conditional𝑌𝑍s.t.𝐼𝑋𝑍conditional𝑋𝑍subscript𝐼𝑐subscript𝑍𝐻conditional𝑌𝑍s.t.𝐻𝑍subscript𝐻𝑐\min_{Z}{I(X;Y|Z)},\ \textit{s.t.}\ I(X-Z;X|Z)\geq I_{c}\Leftrightarrow\min_{Z}H(Y|Z),\ \textit{s.t.}\ H(Z)\leq H_{c}.

Furthermore, we have:

H​(Y|Z)=∫𝐳p​(z)​H​(Y|Z=𝐳)​𝑑𝐳=∫𝐳p​(𝐳)​∫𝐲p​(𝐲|𝐳)​log⁡1p​(𝐲|𝐳)​d​𝐲​d​𝐳=−∫𝐳∫𝐲p​(𝐲,𝐳)​log⁡p​(𝐲|𝐳)​𝑑𝐲​𝑑𝐳=−𝔼​log⁡p​(𝐲|𝐳).H​(Z)≤12​∑i=1dln⁡𝑉𝑎𝑟​(𝐳i)​2​π​e=12​∑i=1dln⁡𝑉𝑎𝑟​(𝐳i)+12​∑i=1dln⁡2​π​e≤12​∑i=1dln⁡𝑉𝑎𝑟​(𝐳i)+12​d​ln⁡ 2​π​e=12​∑i=1dln⁡𝔼​(𝐳i2)+12​d​ln⁡2​π​e=12​ln⁡𝔼​(∑i=1d𝐳i2)+12​d​ln⁡2​π​e≤Hc⇒𝔼​‖𝐳‖22≤e2​Hc−d​ln⁡2​π​e=ρ,formulae-sequence𝐻conditional𝑌𝑍subscript𝐳𝑝𝑧𝐻conditional𝑌𝑍𝐳differential-d𝐳subscript𝐳𝑝𝐳subscript𝐲𝑝conditional𝐲𝐳1𝑝conditional𝐲𝐳𝑑𝐲𝑑𝐳subscript𝐳subscript𝐲𝑝𝐲𝐳𝑝conditional𝐲𝐳differential-d𝐲differential-d𝐳𝔼𝑝conditional𝐲𝐳𝐻𝑍12superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑𝑉𝑎𝑟subscript𝐳𝑖2𝜋𝑒12superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑𝑉𝑎𝑟subscript𝐳𝑖12superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑2𝜋𝑒12superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑𝑉𝑎𝑟subscript𝐳𝑖12𝑑2𝜋𝑒12superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑𝔼superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑖212𝑑2𝜋𝑒12𝔼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑖212𝑑2𝜋𝑒subscript𝐻𝑐⇒𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐳22superscript𝑒2subscript𝐻𝑐𝑑2𝜋𝑒𝜌\begin{split}H(Y|Z)&=\int_{\mathbf{z}}p(z)H(Y|Z=\mathbf{z})d\mathbf{z}=\int_{\mathbf{z}}p(\mathbf{z})\int_{\mathbf{y}}p(\mathbf{y}|\mathbf{z})\log\frac{1}{p(\mathbf{y}|\mathbf{z})}d\mathbf{y}d\mathbf{z}\\ &=-\int_{\mathbf{z}}\int_{\mathbf{y}}p(\mathbf{y},\mathbf{z})\log p(\mathbf{y}|\mathbf{z})d\mathbf{y}d\mathbf{z}\\ &=-\mathbb{E}\log p(\mathbf{y}|\mathbf{z}).\\ H(Z)&\leq\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{d}\ln\mathit{Var}(\mathbf{z}_{i})2\pi e=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{d}\ln\mathit{Var}(\mathbf{z}_{i})+\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{d}\ln 2\pi e\\ &\leq\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{d}\ln\mathit{Var}(\mathbf{z}_{i})+\frac{1}{2}d\ln\ 2\pi e=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{d}\ln\mathbb{E}(\mathbf{z}_{i}^{2})+\frac{1}{2}d\ln 2\pi e\\ &=\frac{1}{2}\ln\mathbb{E}(\sum_{i=1}^{d}\mathbf{z}_{i}^{2})+\frac{1}{2}d\ln 2\pi e\leq H_{c}\\ \Rightarrow&\mathbb{E}||\mathbf{z}||_{2}^{2}\leq e^{2H_{c}-d\ln 2\pi e}=\rho,\end{split} (16)

which completes the proof.

Appendix D Full Analysis on Differentially Private Features

Our security analyses contain two steps, saying, differential privacy for each client and the overall analyses for FedFed. Built upon previous works [27, 16], we derive Lemma D.1 below. For FedFed, we attain Lemma D.2 by limiting σr→∞→subscript𝜎𝑟\sigma_{r}\rightarrow\infty.

Lemma D.1.

For sharing raw features x𝑥x, (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP holds if ϵ′=O​(R​log⁡(1/δ)​(ρ/σs+(1−ρ)/σr))superscriptitalic-ϵ′𝑂𝑅1𝛿𝜌subscript𝜎𝑠1𝜌subscript𝜎𝑟\epsilon^{\prime}=O({\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}}(\rho/{\sigma_{s}}+(1-\rho)/{\sigma_{r}})).

Lemma D.2.

For sharing performance-sensitive features 𝐱ssubscript𝐱𝑠\mathbf{x}_{s}, (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP holds if ϵ=O​(ρ​R​log⁡(1/δ)/σs)italic-ϵ𝑂𝜌𝑅1𝛿subscript𝜎𝑠\epsilon=O({\rho\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}}/{\sigma_{s}}).

D.1 Analysis and Proof for Theorem 3.3

Recall that DP-SGD [27] samples i.i.d. noise from unbias Gaussian distribution 𝒩​(𝟎,Sf2​σ2)𝒩0subscriptsuperscript𝑆2𝑓superscript𝜎2\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0},S^{2}_{f}\sigma^{2}), where Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f} is the sensitivity. At the algorithmic level, the noise sampled from 𝒩​(𝟎,σ2​C2​𝐈)𝒩0superscript𝜎2superscript𝐶2𝐈\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0},\sigma^{2}C^{2}\mathbf{I}) is added to a batch of gradients handled by clipping value C𝐶C.

For aligning analyses with conventional DP guarantees, we adopt similar notations and expressions. Specifically, we denote the noise distribution operated on 𝐱rsubscript𝐱𝑟\mathbf{x}_{r} to be 𝒩​(𝟎,σr2​𝐈)𝒩0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑟𝐈\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0},\sigma^{2}_{r}\mathbf{I}) and the noise distribution operated on 𝐱ssubscript𝐱𝑠\mathbf{x}_{s} to be 𝒩​(𝟎,σs2​𝐈)𝒩0subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑠𝐈\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0},\sigma^{2}_{s}\mathbf{I}). Notably, FedFed only adds DP noise to 𝐱ssubscript𝐱𝑠\mathbf{x}_{s} in practice. Since 𝐱rsubscript𝐱𝑟\mathbf{x}_{r} is kept by the corresponding client, an adversary could attain nothing (or be regarded as random data without any entropy). This could be regarded as adding a sufficiently large noise on 𝐱rsubscript𝐱𝑟\mathbf{x}_{r}, thus we consider the σr→∞→subscript𝜎𝑟\sigma_{r}\rightarrow\infty. As for 𝐱ssubscript𝐱𝑠\mathbf{x}_{s}, we employ the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm clipping when selecting the noise level σssubscript𝜎𝑠\sigma_{s}.

Now, let’s come back to the setting of sharing all raw data 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}. We still regard 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} to be two parts, i.e., 𝐱=𝐱r+𝐱s𝐱subscript𝐱𝑟subscript𝐱𝑠\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{x}_{r}+\mathbf{x}_{s} for the latter comparison to FedFed. This trick is motivated by cryptographic standard proof with ideal/real paradigm [57]. For both 𝐱rsubscript𝐱𝑟\mathbf{x}_{r} and 𝐱ssubscript𝐱𝑠\mathbf{x}_{s}, the noise addition follows DP-SGD’s idea, except for adding noise to the sampled data for updating gradients, rather than the latter-computed real gradients. We remark that this method works for FL but may be different for centralized training (with identical training set in the whole training process).

Using the property of post-processing [16], the noise added to the data passes to (or projects to) the following gradient updates. For the view of each client, we know that Theorem D.3666Previously “≥\geq”, we take the special case “==” the same as DP-SGD. holds for σ𝜎\sigma operated on 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} from [27].

Theorem D.3.

There exist constants c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2} so that given the sampling probability q=L/N𝑞𝐿𝑁q=L/N and the number of steps T𝑇T, for any ϵ<c1​q2​Titalic-ϵsubscript𝑐1superscript𝑞2𝑇\epsilon<c_{1}q^{2}T. The algorithm of DP-SGD is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differentially private for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 if we choose σ=c2​q​T​log⁡(1/δ)ϵ𝜎subscript𝑐2𝑞𝑇1𝛿italic-ϵ\sigma=c_{2}\frac{q\sqrt{T\log(1/\delta)}}{\epsilon}.

For strong composition theorem, the choice of σ𝜎\sigma in Theorem D.3 is O​(q​T​log⁡(1/δ)/ϵ)𝑂𝑞𝑇1𝛿italic-ϵO({q\sqrt{T\log(1/\delta)}}/{\epsilon}). In DP-SGD, the T𝑇T denotes the number of training steps, which means the times of using/sampling private data for DP training. Such meaning represents communication rounds in FL, in which each client receives globally shared data at each round of communication. In the FedFed, we denote the number of communication rounds to be R𝑅R. Now, let’s handle the q𝑞q, where q𝑞q represents the ratio of lot size and the inputting dataset size. In DP-SGD, the per-lot data is directly sampled from the database of size N𝑁N. In other words, a lot of data is the subset of the input dataset. In the FedFed, the training data fed to each client’s model is the same as the database size, i.e., q=N/N=1𝑞𝑁𝑁1q=N/N=1.

DP-SGD asks for the generality and thus bounds ‖f​(⋅)‖=𝐞norm𝑓⋅𝐞\|f(\cdot)\|=\mathbf{e}. Yet, FedFed sets σ∝‖𝐱s‖proportional-to𝜎normsubscript𝐱𝑠\sigma\propto\|\mathbf{x}_{s}\|, which does not ask for a general case. We use the notation ‖𝐱s‖2subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑠2\|\mathbf{x}_{s}\|_{2} to represent the domain of performance-sensitive features. On the other hand, ‖𝐱‖2subscriptnorm𝐱2\|\mathbf{x}\|_{2} represents the domain of all features (namely, the “domain of datasets”). We additionally borrow the definition of l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-norm and move ‖𝐱s‖normsubscript𝐱𝑠\|\mathbf{x}_{s}\| out in the proof. By Equation 8, the client takes ρ​‖𝐱‖𝜌norm𝐱\rho{\|\mathbf{x}\|} for selecting σ𝜎\sigma. Since we aim to make an asymptotic analysis here, we ignore the scalars and constants here. Thus, we attain O​(ρ​R​log⁡(1/δ)/ϵ)𝑂𝜌𝑅1𝛿italic-ϵO({\rho\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}}/{\epsilon}) for selecting σ𝜎\sigma. By rearranging variables, we have ϵ=ρ​R​log⁡(1/δ)/σitalic-ϵ𝜌𝑅1𝛿𝜎\epsilon={\rho\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}}/{\sigma} for a loose analysis.

Before continuing the proof, we derive Lemma D.4 to get the relation between ‖𝐱r‖normsubscript𝐱𝑟\|\mathbf{x}_{r}\| and ‖𝐱‖norm𝐱\|\mathbf{x}\| for latter usage.

Following above, we can establish the relationship between ‖𝐱‖2subscriptnorm𝐱2\|\mathbf{x}\|_{2} and ‖𝐱s‖2subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑠2\|\mathbf{x}_{s}\|_{2} as follows:

where we re-scale data into [0,1]01[0,1] and assume the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm of data is less than M>0𝑀0M>0. To ensure the ‖𝐱e‖2≤ρ​Msubscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑒2𝜌𝑀\|\mathbf{x}_{e}\|_{2}\leq\rho M, we clip the norm for each sample, which is widely used in DP [27]. ∎

Now, let’s go back to derive Lemma D.1 and Lemma D.2, and continue the proof. For sharing raw data 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, we employ the same method as aforementioned. Since ‖𝐱s‖=ρ​‖𝐱‖normsubscript𝐱𝑠𝜌norm𝐱\|\mathbf{x}_{s}\|=\rho\|\mathbf{x}\|, we get ϵe′=ρ​R​log⁡(1/δ)/σssubscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′𝑒𝜌𝑅1𝛿subscript𝜎𝑠\epsilon^{\prime}_{e}=\rho\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}/{\sigma_{s}}. By Lemma D.4, we know that (1−ρ)≤‖𝐱r‖‖𝐱‖≤(1+ρ)1𝜌normsubscript𝐱𝑟norm𝐱1𝜌(1-\rho)\leq\frac{\|\mathbf{x}_{r}\|}{\|\mathbf{x}\|}\leq(1+\rho) holds. Thus, we attain,

(1−ρ)​R​log⁡(1/δ)/σr≤ϵr′≤(1+ρ)​R​log⁡(1/δ)/σr.1𝜌𝑅1𝛿subscript𝜎𝑟subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′𝑟1𝜌𝑅1𝛿subscript𝜎𝑟(1-\rho)\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}/{\sigma_{r}}\leq\epsilon^{\prime}_{r}\leq(1+\rho)\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}/{\sigma_{r}}.

Here, we take ϵr′≥(1−ρ)​R​log⁡(1/δ)/σrsubscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′𝑟1𝜌𝑅1𝛿subscript𝜎𝑟\epsilon^{\prime}_{r}\geq(1-\rho)\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}/{\sigma_{r}} since we expect a loose case. By combining ϵe′subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′𝑒\epsilon^{\prime}_{e} and ϵr′subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′𝑟\epsilon^{\prime}_{r}, we attain,

ϵ′=O​(R​log⁡(1/δ)​(ρ/σs+(1−ρ)/σr))superscriptitalic-ϵ′𝑂𝑅1𝛿𝜌subscript𝜎𝑠1𝜌subscript𝜎𝑟\epsilon^{\prime}=O({\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}}(\rho/{\sigma_{s}}+(1-\rho)/{\sigma_{r}}))

for sharing raw x𝑥x, as Lemma D.1. Now, let’s take FedFed into consideration. The major difference is that 𝐱rsubscript𝐱𝑟\mathbf{x}_{r} is kept locally in the whole training process. The root cause lies in that the 𝐱rsubscript𝐱𝑟\mathbf{x}_{r} owned by the client is privacy-insensitive to this corresponding client. We regard σrsubscript𝜎𝑟\sigma_{r} operated on 𝐱rsubscript𝐱𝑟\mathbf{x}_{r} to be a sufficiently large value. Thus, given ρ≪1much-less-than𝜌1\rho\ll 1, we get,

limσr→∞ϵr=(1−ρ)​R​log⁡(1/δ)/σr→0.subscript→subscript𝜎𝑟subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑟1𝜌𝑅1𝛿subscript𝜎𝑟→0\lim_{\sigma_{r}\rightarrow\infty}\epsilon_{r}={(1-\rho)\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}}/{\sigma_{r}}\rightarrow 0.

That is, for sharing 𝐱ssubscript𝐱𝑠\mathbf{x}_{s} in FedFed, we have ϵ=ϵs=O​(ρ/σs​log⁡(1δ))italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑠𝑂𝜌subscript𝜎𝑠1𝛿\epsilon=\epsilon_{s}=O(\rho/\sigma_{s}\sqrt{\log(\frac{1}{\delta})}), as Lemma D.2.

Let’s conversely think Lemma D.1 and Lemma D.2. Now, the proof in the following is very straightforward. If we take identical σssubscript𝜎𝑠\sigma_{s} operated on 𝐱ssubscript𝐱𝑠\mathbf{x}_{s} for FedFed and sharing raw x𝑥x. We know that ϵ′>ϵsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′italic-ϵ\epsilon^{\prime}>\epsilon. Conversely, if we take identical ϵ,ϵ′italic-ϵsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′\epsilon,\epsilon^{\prime}, we should increase 1/σs1subscript𝜎𝑠1/\sigma_{s} and thus reduce σssubscript𝜎𝑠\sigma_{s}, given constant ρ​R​log⁡(1/δ)𝜌𝑅1𝛿\rho\sqrt{R\log(1/\delta)}. Thus, for protecting training data in FL, we can attain Theorem 3.3 to summarize the superiority of FedFed when asking for an identical privacy guarantee. Theorem 3.3 explains the reason for the superior model performance of FedFed, which intrinsically boils down to a relatively small σ𝜎\sigma compared with sharing raw data 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}.

D.2 Analysis and Proof for Theorem 3.4

Previously, we showcase the view of each client for analyzing privacy. Albeit we do not aim at a new DP theorem, we expect a tighter privacy analysis for FedFed by using the advanced result [28]. Vadhan and Wang [58] prove that when the interactive mechanisms being composed are pure differentially private, their concurrent composition achieves privacy parameters (with respect to pure or approximate differential privacy) that match the (optimal) composition theorem for noninteractive differential privacy. To be specific, we follow the proof logic of Theorem D.7 [28] for analyzing globally shared data from all clients.

Given (ϵk,δ)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘𝛿(\epsilon_{k},\delta)-DP at each client side, we utilize the composition theorem to analyze overall privacy in FedFed. The concept of sensitivity below is originally used for sharing a dataset for achieving (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy.

Definition D.5 (Sensitivity [28]).

The sensitivity of a query function ℱ:𝔻→ℝ:ℱ→𝔻ℝ\mathcal{F}:\mathbb{D}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} for any two neighboring datasets D,D′𝐷superscript𝐷′D,D^{\prime} is Δ=maxD,D′⁡‖ℱ​(D)−ℱ​(D′)‖Δsubscript𝐷superscript𝐷′normℱ𝐷ℱsuperscript𝐷′\Delta=\max_{D,D^{\prime}}\|\mathcal{F}(D)-\mathcal{F}(D^{\prime})\|, where ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| denotes L1subscript𝐿1L_{1} or L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} norm.

Privacy loss is a random variable that accumulates the random noise added to the algorithm/model, which is utilized in Theorem D.7.

Definition D.6 (Privacy Loss [28]).

. Let ℳ:𝔻→ℝ:ℳ→𝔻ℝ\mathcal{M}:\mathbb{D}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} be a randomized mechanism with input domain D𝐷D and range R𝑅R. Let D,D′𝐷superscript𝐷′D,D^{\prime} be a pair of adjacent dataset and 𝖺𝗎𝗑𝖺𝗎𝗑\mathsf{aux} be an auxiliary input. For an outcome o∈ℝ𝑜ℝo\in\mathbb{R}, the privacy loss at o𝑜o is defined by ℒ𝖯𝗋𝗂(o)≜log⁡(Pr​[ℳ​(𝖺𝗎𝗑,D)=o]/Pr​[ℳ​(𝖺𝗎𝗑,D′)=o])≜superscriptsubscriptℒ𝖯𝗋𝗂𝑜Prdelimited-[]ℳ𝖺𝗎𝗑𝐷𝑜Prdelimited-[]ℳ𝖺𝗎𝗑superscript𝐷′𝑜\mathcal{L}_{\mathsf{Pri}}^{(o)}\triangleq\log({{\rm Pr}[\mathcal{M}(\mathsf{aux},D)=o]}/{{\rm Pr}[\mathcal{M}(\mathsf{aux},D^{\prime})=o]}).

Theorem D.7 (Composition Theorem [28]).

For any ϵ>0,δ∈[0,1]formulae-sequenceitalic-ϵ0𝛿01\epsilon>0,\delta\in[0,1], and δ^∈[0,1]^𝛿01\hat{\delta}\in[0,1], the class of (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differentially private mechanisms satisfies (ϵ^δ^,1−(1−δ^)​Πi​(1−δi))subscript^italic-ϵ^𝛿11^𝛿subscriptΠ𝑖1subscript𝛿𝑖(\hat{\epsilon}_{\hat{\delta}},1-(1-\hat{\delta})\Pi_{i}(1-\delta_{i}))-differential privacy under k𝑘k-fold adaptive composition for ϵ^δ^=min{kϵ,(eϵ−1)ϵk/(eϵ+1)+ϵ2klog(e+k​ϵ2/δ^),(eϵ−1)ϵk/(eϵ+1)+ϵ2​k​log⁡(1/δ^)}\hat{\epsilon}_{\hat{\delta}}=\min\{k\epsilon,(e^{\epsilon}-1)\epsilon k/(e^{\epsilon}+1)+\epsilon\sqrt{2k\log(e+\sqrt{k\epsilon^{2}/\hat{\delta}}}),(e^{\epsilon}-1)\epsilon k/(e^{\epsilon}+1)+\epsilon\sqrt{2k\log(1/\hat{\delta})}\}.

Proof.

Definition D.6 gets ℒ𝖯𝗋𝗂(o)superscriptsubscriptℒ𝖯𝗋𝗂𝑜\mathcal{L}_{\mathsf{Pri}}^{(o)} on an outcome variable o𝑜o over databases D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}. Let ℛ​(ϵ,δ)ℛitalic-ϵ𝛿\mathcal{R}(\epsilon,\delta) be privacy region of a single access to ℳ†superscriptℳ†\mathcal{M}^{{\dagger}}. The privacy region consists of two rejection regions with errors, i.e., rejecting true null-hypothesis (type-I error) and retaining false null-hypothesis (type-II error). Let ϵk†,δk†subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ†𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝛿†𝑘\epsilon^{\dagger}_{k},\delta^{\dagger}_{k} be ℳi†subscriptsuperscriptℳ†𝑖\mathcal{M}^{{\dagger}}_{i}’s parameters for defining privacy. Now, by Lemma D.2, we get Theorem 3.4 directly. In summary, FedFed protects two types of data features using two different protective manners, i.e., small noise for performance-sensitive features and extremely large noise for performance-robust features, and thus attains higher model performance and stronger security in the same time.

Appendix E More Results on Attack

E.1 More Details on Model Inversion Attack

In this section, we present additional results of the model inversion attack. When the central server assumes the role of the attacker without access to the original data, it exhibits a diminished performance in attacking the model. The raw data 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} of Figure 3 (a) and (b) can be found in Figure 6(a). As we can see, 𝐱ssubscript𝐱𝑠\mathbf{x}_{s} still causes privacy leakage and Figure 6(b) also gives the intuitive necessity of DP protection on 𝐱ssubscript𝐱𝑠\mathbf{x}_{s}.

Inspired by generative model inversion methods [40, 59], we conduct another experiment where one of the clients acts as the attacker. Similar to GMI [40], the method involves leveraging an auxiliary dataset and a public dataset to launch an attack on the target model. In our experiments, we utilize the globally shared dataset as the auxiliary dataset, while the local private data serves as the public dataset because the client has access to its own local data. Under this scenario (results in Figure 7), the attacker’s performance is better than when the server acts as the attacker, while the attacker is still unable to recover data from the shared features. The model architectures of generative-based model inversion attack are listed in Table 8.

E.2 More Details on Membership Inference Attack

Is Theorem 3.3 true empirically?

Membership inference attack(MIA) [41, 15] attempts to infer whether a particular data point is in the target model’s training set.

Specifically, the global model on the server side can be regarded as the target model in FL. In our setting, we train a shadow model with globally shared data. Then the membership attack can be regarded as a binary classification task, member data or non-member data. The input of the attack model is the top-k vector of the output from the shadow model. To compare the superiority of sharing partial data rather than the complete data with DP, we conduct MIA to explore the divergence experimentally. Sharing raw data causes more information leakage (higher recall of MIA) than partial data with the same DP level. However, the FedFed needs a relatively small noise σ𝜎\sigma to achieve comparable protection. The attack process is shown in Figure 8.

F.1 Visualization of Data Heterogeneity

And the Subset partition only has the label skew. #​C=k#𝐶𝑘\#C=k means each client only has k𝑘k different labels from dataset, and k𝑘k controls the unbalanced degree. The subset method makes each client have all classes from the data, but one dominant class far away outnumbers other classes.
